messages.text:
I think it'd be better than snap
Plus it might save the trouble of making binaries for every distro out there
Plus, Yggdrasil will see more and more recipes everyday
Honestly, I think both ygg and BB are worth heavily promoting and popularizing

messages.text:
does anyone actually use julia in CentOS 6?  I'm trying to install Yggdrasil ccache in the docker image of CentOS 6, but
```[root@a0dc056fc7db /]# ccache 
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.18' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `CXXABI_1.3.5' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.14' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.17' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.15' not found (required by ccache)```
it comes with libstdc++ corresponding to gcc 4.4.7, which is even much older than our oldest version of GCC

elements.text: does anyone actually use julia in CentOS 6?  I'm trying to install Yggdrasil ccache in the docker image of CentOS 6, but

ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.18' not found (required by ccache)

ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.15' not found (required by ccache)
it comes with libstdc++ corresponding to gcc 4.4.7, which is even much older than our oldest version of GCC

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/MayaPosch|@MayaPosch>: <https://twitter.com/mrcbergamin|@mrcbergamin> I was tossed into CMake the first time during a big commercial project, during which I found myself fighting with the utter brokenness that was CMake's cross-platform/cross-compilation support, passing in different sysroots and toolchains.

Moved to just Make, and it just worked.
attachments.text:
<https://twitter.com/mrcbergamin|@mrcbergamin> I was tossed into CMake the first time during a big commercial project, during which I found myself fighting with the utter brokenness that was CMake's cross-platform/cross-compilation support, passing in different sysroots and toolchains.

Moved to just Make, and it just worked.

messages.text:
People of BinaryBuilder...
I'm confused with one thing...
Musl C and glib C....
If both compile for the same architecture.... example x86_64 linux
Wouldn't the binary created by both musl C and glib C, run in that architecture
They're just different libc implementations, not compilers.....

Why compile with both musl C and glibc?

elements.text:
People of BinaryBuilder...
I'm confused with one thing...
Musl C and glib C....
If both compile for the same architecture.... example x86_64 linux
Wouldn't the binary created by both musl C and glib C, run in that architecture
They're just different libc implementations, not compilers.....

Why compile with both musl C and glibc?

messages.text:
Assume I'm using
glibc to compile for a platform W, it outputs a binary called gw
musl to compile for a platform W, it outputs a binary called mw
If `./gw` and `./mw`, both work on W, isn't one of gw or mw enough? Why do we need to build both of them....? What are the consequences of using ./gw on aarch64 Alpine Linux?

messages.text: Say I have some Fortran 90 code that I want to compile with BinaryBuilder. It uses MPICH's mpif90 for compiling, but MPICH_jll doesn't expose that as a build product. Would I have to amend the recipe for MPICH to expose mpif90, or will it be available but "hidden" somehow?

elements.text: Say I have some Fortran 90 code that I want to compile with BinaryBuilder. It uses MPICH's mpif90 for compiling, but MPICH_jll doesn't expose that as a build product. Would I have to amend the recipe for MPICH to expose mpif90, or will it be available but "hidden" somehow?

messages.text:
Hi all, how can I help BinaryBuilder find a binary that it has built?

<https://dev.azure.com/JuliaPackaging/Yggdrasil/_build/results?buildId=8874&view=logs&jobId=fd4c1e15-3e0d-527f-068f-6e9a4ef6c0ee&j=fd4c1e15-3e0d-527f-068f-6e9a4ef6c0ee&t=62c800ed-eb5b-51e5-ad07-ccd3e70a1cb7|https://dev.azure.com/JuliaPackaging/Yggdrasil/_build/results?buildId=8874&view=log[…]-527f-068f-6e9a4ef6c0ee&t=62c800ed-eb5b-51e5-ad07-ccd3e70a1cb7>

I'm assuming the problem is that it isn't looking in `/usr/local/bin`?

Thanks!

elements.text: Hi all, how can I help BinaryBuilder find a binary that it has built?
https://dev.azure.com/JuliaPackaging/Yggdrasil/_build/results?buildId=8874&view=log[…]-527f-068f-6e9a4ef6c0ee&t=62c800ed-eb5b-51e5-ad07-ccd3e70a1cb7
I'm assuming the problem is that it isn't looking in
/usr/local/bin

?

Thanks!

messages.text: Did you set the prefix?

elements.text: Did you set the prefix?

messages.text: Nope : )

elements.text: Nope : )

messages.text: prefix=${prefix}

elements.text: prefix=${prefix}

messages.text: BB will pick up everything it can find in ${prefix}

elements.text: BB will pick up everything it can find in ${prefix}

messages.text: yes, this is summarised here: <https://docs.binarybuilder.org/stable/build_tips/#Build-strategy>

elements.text: yes, this is summarised here:

messages.text: Thanks!

elements.text: Thanks!

messages.text: looks like the variable to use is `PREFIX`: <https://github.com/mapbox/tippecanoe/blob/4bb73aa6bca22da401898b0d9c55906559159b5d/Makefile#L1>

elements.text: looks like the variable to use is
PREFIX

messages.text: haha, I was just going to try that without looking. Thanks

crypto_auth/hmacsha512/.libs/libsodium_la-auth_hmacsha512.o crypto_auth/hmacsha512256/.libs/libsodium_la-auth_hmacsha512256.o crypto_box/.libs/libsodium_la-crypto_box.o
